some things i put in a to-do list, i ended up doing/getting after several years.

what also happens here is that over time, as more people figure out stuff for themselves and write about it, more aspects of reality get mapped out and articulated, which others then borrow to make sense of their own reality. (or use to merely feign understanding.)

the words, no matter how rich in their description, are never the thing being described. as a result, you see two things happen:

- students figuring out things for themselves arriving at cliches and platitudes and seeing them in an entirely profound and insightful light

- grifters and frameworkcels turning profound and insightful articulations into mere cliches and platitudes due to liberal use without understanding

when you're really figuring things out for yourself, the learnings you accrue are so haphazard and piecemeal that your conditioned, clean-narrative-seeking mind doesn't even see them as such. 

we are trained to think of insight as something that reads like a textbook ‚Äî with a proper structure, hierarchy, and logical flow. but that's you simply connecting dots post-facto. the real learning has happened in a way and form you cannot articulate, because the totality of experience in any given moment doesn't confine itself to the linear structure of language.

that's why real learning often feels uncomfortable. not because it's hard work, but because our brains struggle to make sense of it. hard work that you can constantly track progress on, with tight feedback loops, doesn't feel hard. it feels enjoyable.

but with learning that feels hard, what's really happening is that we can't package it up into a neat little story to tell ourselves, so we end up feeling confused and unsatisfied. our minds are constantly trying to convince themselves that they've learned something, but until we can articulate it clearly, we feel unsettled.

the kind of learning that increases life XP has loose feedback loops, if any. it is chaotic, accrues randomly, and doesn't look like an insightful essay at all. in fact, the essay is an artificial condensation of a much haphazard, discontinuous, and unstructured process, and in that, it misses the essence of how the learning accrued. because the essence cannot be articulated.

a corollary to this is that if you can immediately articulate something you've learned, you've likely not learned anything deeply valuable.
